Professional JS for Developers

This is a project I have put together from the book Professional JS for Developers by Nicholas C Zakas

See One, Do One, Teach One

Data Types - There are 5, maybe 6

  • Undefined - variable declared but not initialized!
  • Null - empty object pointer
  • Boolean - only two values true or false
  • Number - integers and floating point values
  • String - sequence of 0 or more 16-unicode characters
  • Object - groups of data and functionality
var message = "some string";
console.log(typeof (message)); //object

String Character Literals

  • \n - new line
  • \t - tab
  • \b - backspace
  • \r - carriage return
  • \f - form feed
  • \\ - backslash
  • \' - single quote
  • \" - double quotes

Converting values to String

var num =10;
console.log( num.toString() );

Object properties and methods

  • Constructor - function that was used to create the object
  • hasOwnProperty(property name) - indicates whether or not object exists on instance
  • isPrototypeOf(object) - indicates whether or not object is a prototype of another object
  • propertyIsEnumerable(property name) - indicates whether the object can be enumerated with for-in statement
  • toLocaleString() - returns string representation of the object appropriate for locale environment
  • toString() - returns string representation of object
  • valueOf() - returns string, number or boolean of object
Top

Arguments are values or valuables that are passed in functions

Top

Objects

Creating Objects

var person = new Object();
person.name = "Nicholas";
person.age = 29;

Or to use the Object Literal Notation

var person = {
name: "Nicholas",
age: 29
}

Top

Calling Objects

alert( person["name"] );
alert( person.name );

It's better to use bracket notation as you can substitute variables or use properties with spaces

Top

Array Types!

Creating Arrays

Array Constructor Method

var colors = new Array();

Array Literal Notation

var colors = [];

Top

To Get and Set Arrays, use BRACKETS

var colors = ["red", "blue", "yellow"];
colors2[2] = "black";

'join' Method

var colors = ["red", "green", "blue"];
alert( colors.join(", ") ); //red, green, blue
alert( colors.join("||") ); //red || green || blue

'join' method combines elements in array and inserts specified character to separate them.

Top

Array Stack Methods

Arrays have the ability to be converted to stack arrays that allow them to behave like other data structures. They are referred to as L-I-F-O, "Last In First Out".

The insertion is called a push and the removal is called a pop. Push() methods accept arguments and adds them to the end of the array and returns the array's length. The pop() method removes the last item in the array, updates the length, and returns the item.

var colors = new Array();
var count = colors.push( "red", "yellow" );
alert( count ); //2

var item = colors.pop();
alert( item ); //yellow

Top

Queue Methods

Just like stacks only allow for L-I-F-O, queues restrict access to F-I-F-O, First In First Out. This is achieved with the shift() method, which removes the first item in the array, returns it, and decreases the length by one.

var colors = new Array();
var count = colors.push( "yellow", "black" );
var item = colors.shift();
alert(item); //yellow

The opposite is the unshift() method which just adds item to the front of the array.

Top

Reordering Arrays

Two methods deal with the reordering of elements already in an array: reverse() and sort().

var values = [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ];
values.reverse();
alert( values ); //5, 4, 3, 2, 1

When it comes to sort(), this will take the string value, not the numeric value. If you want it to sort from lowest to greatest by numerical value, you need to pass in the comparison argument.

var values = [ 0, 1, 5, 10, 15 ];
values.sort();
console.log(values) // 0, 1, 10, 15, 5

function compare(value1, value2){
if(value1 < value2){
return -1;
}else if( value2 < value1 ){
return 1;
}else{
return 0;
}
}

values.sort(compare);
console.log(values); //0, 1, 5, 10, 15

To return the values in descending order, just change the return value for the first two conditionals to their opposite.

Top

Manipulating Arrays

The next method we will learn is called the concat() method, which copies the array, appends any items to the array that are passed as the argument, and returns the newly created array.

var colors = [ "red", "blue", "yellow" ];
var colors2 = colors.concat("blacK", "green");

alert(colors2); //red, blue, yellow, black, green

The next method to look at is the slice() method. The slice() method accepts one or two arguments and returns an array from elements already in the array. The arguments it accepts are the starting and ending points, not including the ending point. This does not effect the original array.

var colors = ["red", "blue", "green", "yellow", "purple"];
var colors2 = colors.slice(1);
var colors3 = colors.slice(1,4);

alert( colors2 ); //blue, green, yellow, purple
alert( colors3 ); //blue, green, yellow

Splice() Method

One of the most powerful array manipulation methods is splice() which allows you to inject items to the middle of an array. There are three distinct ways to use it:

  • Deletion - Any number of items in an array can be removed just by passing in the starting and ending point of what you want to remove. splice(0,2) deletes the first two items.
  • Insertion - Items can be inserted into an array by passing in three arguments: starting position, number of items to delete, and the item to insert. splice(2, 0, "red", "green")
  • Replacement - Items can be inserted at a specific position while simultaneously deleting items from the array. See above.
Top

Location Methods

There are two methods to find the location of an item in an array: indexOf() and lastIndexOf(). Both accept two arguments. The item to look for and an optional starting point in the array. indexOf() starts at the beginning and lastIndexOf() starts at the end. Both return the position of the item in the array or -1 if not found.

Top

Iterative Methods

There are five methods for iterating through arrays. Each method accepts two arguments: a function to run on each item, and an optional scope object on which to run the function. The function passed into this method will receive three arguments: the array item value, the position, and the array object.

  • every() - runs function on every item in array and returns true if function is true for EVERY item.
  • filter() - runs function on every item in array and returns array of items for which case is true.
  • forEach() - runs function on every item in array and has NO return.
  • map() - runs function on every item in array and returns result of each function call in an array.
  • some() - runs function on every item in array and returns true if function is true for at least one item.
Top
